oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 37570 LOOKING TOWARD TENNESSEE FROM THE TOP OF CLINGMAN'S DOME, GREAT SMOKY MOUNTAINS Clingman's Dome is the topmost peak in the park. From this elevation of 6,642 feet there is an unobstructed view of timbered ridges, shared equally by North Carolina and Tennessee. Their axes run almost east and west for fifty-four miles and at no point does the area exceed nineteen miles in width. Great honor is due the naturalists who returned to untold hardships year after year in order to explore this fastness and reveal its true import to our nation. In some 700 square miles more varieties of plants have been found than in any other equal area in the temperate zone. Included in the list are all of those growing along the Atlantic from Canada to Georgia. To better comprehend the botanical wealth of the region a few figures may help. There are 129 species of trees alone. This is significant when one recalls that in all of Europe there are only eighty-five. Flowering plants contribute 1,200 varieties while fungi, mosses, lichens and liverworts add 1,600 more to the grand total. Even with all of these, the possibilities are still far from exhausted. Two hundred thousand of the 428,000 acres are covered with virgin spruce and hardwoods, the only stand of their kind left in this country. Trails or paths, spelling certain disaster to the uninitiated, are the sole means of access to this hinterland where matted luxuriant undergrowth bridges many of the streams, hiding them so completely that their presence would be undetected except for the gurgling, bubbling sounds of the water. Yes, adventure still abounds, even for those hardy individ- ualists who mutter objections as civilization makes inroads and establishes its footholds.
